summary: An analysis of a panel discussion on violent extremism and migration, featuring introductions, audience questions, and expert responses.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a woman standing on a stage, delivering a speech at an event organized by the Mo Ibrahim Foundation, as indicated by the logo in the background. She is dressed in a silver blazer over a black top, accessorized with a pearl necklace and glasses, and holds a red notebook in her left hand. Her right hand gestures as she speaks, emphasizing her points. A man in a suit is seated behind her, attentively listening. The text overlay identifies her as Jendayi Frazer, President and CEO of 50 Ventures, LLC. The setting is formal, with a clean, white backdrop and a professional atmosphere. Throughout the video, Frazer continues to speak, occasionally looking to her left, possibly addressing someone off-camera or referring to notes. The man behind her remains seated, maintaining his focus on her presentation. The video captures the essence of a professional conference or seminar, highlighting Frazer's engagement and the attentive audience.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a female speaker introducing a discussion on violent extremism and migration with a renowned panel. She lays out the schedule for the session, including discussion among the panel, followed by questions from Mo Ibrahim fellows and scholars, and then opening it up to the broader audience. The speaker adopts a professional and clear tone throughout her announcement.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a woman standing on a stage, dressed in a silver jacket and black top, holding a book and speaking to an audience. She is wearing glasses and a pearl necklace, and her expression is serious and focused. In the background, a man in a suit is seated, listening attentively. The backdrop displays the logo of the Mo Ibrahim Foundation, which consists of a colorful circular design with the foundation's name written below it. The setting appears to be a formal event or conference, with a professional atmosphere. The woman's gestures and body language suggest she is delivering a speech or presentation, engaging with the audience. The video captures her movements as she shifts her position slightly, indicating a dynamic and interactive presentation.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker began by introducing a panel. After this introduction, the speaker indicated they would be sitting down and introducing the panelists.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a formal event hosted by the Mo Ibrahim Foundation, as indicated by the backdrop displaying the foundation's logo. It begins with a woman dressed in a grey blazer and black top, holding a notebook and pen, suggesting she is either taking notes or preparing to speak. The scene transitions to a man in a black suit, identified by on-screen text as Youssef Amrani, a Member of The Royal Cabinet, who appears to be listening intently with his hand on his chin. The video then shifts to a man dressed in traditional attire, including a white turban and a green robe with intricate patterns, standing in front of the same backdrop. The setting is professional and formal, with a focus on the speakers and their roles within the event. The atmosphere is one of serious discussion and engagement, as evidenced by the attentive postures and the presence of the foundation's branding throughout the video.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a speaker introducing guests, including "our host, Yousef Amrani," and another person, a member of the Royal Cabinet, along with Emir Muhammadu Sanusi II. The speaker notes the Emir's nobility and Islamic scholarship.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a panel discussion at the Mo Ibrahim Foundation event, with a focus on various speakers. The first speaker, a woman in a grey blazer and black top, is seen holding a book and speaking, with the Mo Ibrahim Foundation logo visible in the background. The scene transitions to a man in a light grey suit and dark tie, identified as Jean-Marie Guehenno, President and CEO of the International Crisis Group, who is also speaking. The video then shows a wider shot of the panel, including five individuals seated on stage, with the Mo Ibrahim Foundation logo prominently displayed. The panelists are dressed in formal attire, with one wearing a traditional green outfit. The focus shifts to Martin Kobler, a Special Representative and Head of the United Nations Support Mission in Libya, who is seen speaking and gesturing. The video concludes with a return to the woman in the grey blazer, who continues to speak while holding her book, with the Mo Ibrahim Foundation logo in the background. The setting is professional and formal, with a red carpet and stage lighting enhancing the atmosphere of the event.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a female speaker introducing Jean-Marie Guehenno, President and CEO of the International Crisis Group, and Martin Kobler, a career diplomat and veteran of the German Foreign Service. The speaker has a formal, clear speaking tone. She ends the clip by saying "very much, Ayat". After the speaker has finished, there is a moment of silence before a short, nondescript musical interlude.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a panel discussion on a stage, featuring five individuals seated in a row. The central figure, dressed in traditional attire with a white turban and a green robe, is flanked by four men in suits. The backdrop displays the text "Mo Durahtim" alongside a logo, indicating the event's theme or sponsor. The audience, seated in front of the stage, is attentively watching the panelists. The scene transitions to a woman with curly hair, wearing a green top and a lanyard, standing and speaking into a microphone. She gestures with her hands as she addresses the audience, who are seated and listening intently. The background shows other attendees and a man in a suit standing behind her. The video captures the woman's expressive delivery, emphasizing her engagement with the audience. The setting remains consistent, with a formal atmosphere and a focus on the speakers and their interactions.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a woman introducing herself, stating her origins from Tunisia, and her experiences as a scholar. She speaks of her thesis topic relating to youth radicalization and recruitment in Tunisia and Kenya. Then she shares a personal story about her cousin's radicalization and their attempts to deradicalize him. She then begins to express her perspectives on the issue, stating there are states that project fear to justify treating young people as terrorism suspects. She questions whether deradicalization policies are furthering youth radicalization, and if the UN's strategy is giving states a free hand to violate youth rights. She feels that the state response to terrorism is typically retributive, resulting in collective punishment of young people.

events_list.video_caption: The video captures a formal event where a woman with curly hair, dressed in a green top with intricate embroidery and a white skirt, is speaking into a microphone. She is actively engaging with the audience, using hand gestures to emphasize her points. The background shows a group of attentive individuals, some in suits, seated and standing, indicating a professional setting. The scene transitions to a panel of five individuals seated on stage, dressed in formal attire, with a backdrop featuring the logo of the Mo Ibrahim Foundation, suggesting the event is related to this organization. The video then returns to the woman speaking, maintaining her expressive gestures and the same attentive audience in the background. The atmosphere is one of focused engagement, with the woman as the central figure delivering her speech.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a female speaker discussing reports on Africa, noting that "the more the state violence against civilians, the more we see terrorism in the country." She contrasts this with UN and state programs focused on building a culture of peace for youth, but argues that security forces are the ones who need non-violent communication first. The speaker continues by mentioning youth agency.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a woman standing in front of a microphone, speaking to an audience. She is wearing a green top with intricate patterns and a white skirt, and her curly hair is styled in loose waves. She holds the microphone in her right hand and gestures with her left hand as she speaks. The background shows a group of people seated, some of whom are wearing suits, indicating a formal event or conference setting. The lighting is warm, and the atmosphere appears to be attentive and engaged. The scene then transitions to a different woman seated at a table, wearing a textured pink blazer over a black top, with a pearl necklace. Behind her is a backdrop with the text "Mo Ibrahim Foundation" and a colorful logo, suggesting that the event is related to this foundation. The woman appears to be listening or preparing to speak, with a bottle of water on the table in front of her. The video captures a moment of interaction and engagement at a formal event, highlighting the speakers and the attentive audience.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a female speaker questioning the idea that young people join terrorist groups due to helplessness, joblessness, and desperation. She suggests this argument is invalidated by facts and data. Her tone is thoughtful and analytical. She posits that the perception of injustice, rather than lack of employment, drives violent extremism and that the issue goes beyond employment and concerns inequality. She then turns to a second point, mentioning the "legitimization of power" of the state.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a woman with curly hair is seen speaking into a microphone, wearing a green top with a decorative neckline and a white skirt. She is actively gesturing with her hands, emphasizing her points as she addresses an audience. The setting appears to be a formal event or conference, with attendees seated in the background, some of whom are dressed in business attire. The atmosphere is professional, and the woman seems to be delivering a passionate speech or presentation. The lighting is focused on her, highlighting her as the central figure in the scene.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a female speaker describing how young people view extremist groups, suggesting that these groups provide something that nation-states do not, such as having "no visa restrictions." She also wonders why young Tunisians form the highest number of foreign fighters in one of these groups. She continues by challenging the status quo and says Daesh stands as a policy preference. She then shifts the topic, asking the audience about where the threat is, speaking in a contemplative manner.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a woman with curly hair is seen speaking into a microphone, wearing a green top with a decorative pattern and a white skirt. She is actively gesturing with her hands, indicating she is engaged in delivering a speech or presentation. The audience, consisting of people in formal attire, is seated and attentively listening to her. The setting appears to be a conference or seminar room with a wooden panel background, creating a professional atmosphere. The woman's facial expressions and body language suggest she is passionate and confident in her delivery. The audience members are focused on her, with some individuals visible in the background, including a man in a suit standing behind her. The overall scene conveys a sense of engagement and interaction between the speaker and the audience.
events_list.audio_caption: A woman speaks in a conversational tone, mentioning that "Daesh is the ultimate threat" and that violence around the world is mainly in homicides and crimes, which takes place in the United States and South America, not Africa. She asks if it's "really true" that her region is the most dangerous.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a series of pie charts illustrating the distribution of the global youth population across different regions, with a focus on Africa. The charts show significant growth in Africa's youth population from 1950 to 2100, with Africa's youth population increasing from 9% to 47% of the global youth population. The charts are accompanied by a timeline and a table listing the actual and projected youth population in millions for various regions. The scene then transitions to a world map titled "The drugs octopus," depicting the routes of drug trafficking from West Africa to various parts of the world, including Europe, the Americas, and Asia. The map uses different colored lines to represent the trafficking of cocaine, heroin, and other drugs, highlighting the global impact of drug trafficking originating from West Africa. Following this, the video presents a bar graph titled "Terrorism, social exclusion, corruption," which ranks the top ten African countries with the highest levels of terrorism, social exclusion, and corruption indicators. The graph compares the average scores of these countries with the continental average scores, emphasizing the challenges faced by African nations in these areas. The video then shifts to a panel discussion featuring five individuals seated on a stage, with the backdrop displaying the logo "Mo Ibrahim Foundation." The panelists, dressed in formal attire, engage in a discussion, with one individual in traditional attire seated in the center. The audience, visible in the foreground, is attentively watching the panelists, with some members clapping and others taking notes. The video concludes with a close-up of the audience, capturing their reactions and engagement with the discussion, highlighting the importance of the topics being addressed.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a female speaker addressing an audience, mentioning the revolution in Tunisia and the focus on countering violent extremism through financial support from many countries. She points out the lack of support for combating trafficking and human trafficking, investing in youth and employment, combating violence against women, and addressing desertification, while emphasizing that the biggest threat to Tunisia in the next ten years is drought and floods. The speaker ends her address with a thankful "Thank you." Following this, applause can be heard. The clip concludes with a man saying "Tough question, I think."

events_list.video_caption: The video features a panel discussion at the Mo Ibrahim Foundation event, with a diverse group of speakers seated on stage. The central figure, dressed in a traditional green robe and white headgear, is flanked by individuals in business attire, including a woman in a grey blazer and pearl necklace, and a man in a light grey suit with a blue polka dot tie. The backdrop prominently displays the Mo Ibrahim Foundation logo, a colorful circular design with the text "Mo Ibrahim Foundation" beneath it. The audience, composed of men and women in formal wear, attentively watches the proceedings. The speakers engage in a dynamic exchange, with the man in the grey suit gesturing as he speaks, while the woman in the grey blazer listens intently. The atmosphere is professional and focused, with the stage and backdrop providing a consistent visual theme throughout the discussion.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a female voice asking if anyone wants to address a certain issue, followed by laughter. A male speaker then says "No, a tough act to follow." A different male speaker states he takes it as a statement. The initial male speaker responds, "That's exactly what I want to say." The first male speaker then begins to discuss the country with the highest rate of violent death per 100,000, after Syria. He reveals it to be El Salvador and states that it makes a point strongly, and discusses how crime has become a way of life in El Salvador and the distinction between crime and politics has disappeared.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a formal event with a panel discussion, where two men are seated on stage, each holding a microphone. The man on the left is dressed in a light gray suit with a white shirt and a dark blue tie with white polka dots, while the man on the right wears a black suit with a white shirt and a dark blue tie. The backdrop displays the logo of the Mo Ibrahim Foundation, which includes a colorful circular design and the text "Mo Ibrahim Foundation." The man in the black suit is actively speaking, using hand gestures to emphasize his points, while the man in the gray suit listens attentively. The audience, visible in the foreground, appears engaged, with some individuals clapping. The setting is professional, with a focus on the speakers and the foundation's branding. The video captures the dynamic interaction between the speakers and the audience, highlighting the importance of the event.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features one male speaker addressing a group, possibly during a conference or meeting. He acknowledges a previous speaker, noting the raising of crucial questions, and expressing that these questions were then answered. The speaker quotes, "You said, you didn't understand how a young Tunisian graduate from engineering, get radicalized." He draws a parallel to a similar situation in France or Belgium and notes the perplexing reality of individuals with education and good jobs choosing to fight. The speaker's tone suggests a thoughtful and concerned discussion of complex issues.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a map of Africa highlighting areas at risk of drought, marked with various colors and symbols indicating different levels of risk and population density. The map is titled "African land at risk of drought." The scene then transitions to another map of Africa, this time focusing on areas at risk of flooding, with similar color coding and symbols to indicate risk levels and population density. The title of this map reads "African land at risk of flooding." Following the maps, the video shifts to a man in a suit speaking at a conference, with the Mo Ibrahim Foundation logo visible in the background. The man is gesturing with his hands as he speaks, emphasizing his points. The video concludes with the man continuing to speak, with the same background and setting, indicating a formal and professional atmosphere.
events_list.audio_caption: A man speaks about the importance of climate change, saying it's a major cause of migration, and he hopes to discuss it further in the future. He speaks in a formal and somewhat didactic tone. His speech is punctuated by applause at the end of his statement.

events_list.video_caption: The video captures a formal event titled "Africa at a Tipping Point," featuring a panel discussion on a stage with a red carpet. The panelists, dressed in formal attire, are seated in front of a backdrop displaying the Mo Ibrahim Foundation logo. The central figure, distinguished by a traditional green robe and white headgear, is flanked by other panelists in suits. The audience, composed of a diverse group of attendees, is shown clapping, indicating their engagement and appreciation. The atmosphere is professional and attentive, with the focus on the panelists' discussion and the audience's response. The video transitions between close-ups of the panelists and wider shots of the stage and audience, emphasizing the event's significance and the collective participation of the attendees.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a female speaker thanking a distinguished panel and the audience for their insights and participation. Her tone is appreciative and concluding. This is followed by applause, suggesting a positive response from the audience and the end of a presentation or discussion.
